name: accommodative
content:
accommodative adjective
(HELPFUL)
Add to word list
Add to word list
willing to give someone what they want or need, or to change in order to suit them: accommodative of The staff were reliable, punctual, and very accommodative of our needs. Her quiet confidence and accommodative nature were evident when we played together as children. Related word
accommodate
More examplesFewer examplesHe accused the nation of being too accommodative towards other states' illegal and terrorist activities.

accommodative adjective
(FINANCE)
finance & economics
  specialized intended to encourage economic growth by reducing interest rates (= the amount charged when people borrow money): He proposes to adopt a cautiously accommodative monetary policy. She believed that interest rates were too accommodative.
More examplesFewer examplesToday’s increase is modest and still leaves rates at very accommodative levels.Global financial conditions remain accommodative, not restrictive.

accommodative adjective
(EYES)
medical
  specialized relating to the way that the eyes adjust (= move and change) in order to focus (= see clearly): Patients undergoing cataract surgery can be fitted with accommodative intraocular lenses. The study looked at the effects of acute accommodative and pupillary dysfunction.
